awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Network of Grades 3-5 Educators for Computational Thinking for English Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
Though Hispanics and English learners constitute two of the fastest growing segments of the K-12 student population, little is known about effective ways of teaching computational thinking to students in these groups, especially at the elementary school level. In the first stage of this project, the research team developed an innovative curriculum that included standards matching, language scaffolds, and culturally-relevant pedagogy to meet the needs of Hispanics and English learners and piloted a wide range of measures to assess the impact on learning processes and outcomes. Building on this successful Research-Practice Partnership between the University of California, Irvine, and Santa Ana Unified School District, the project will iteratively research and develop an approach for teaching computational thinking to SAUSD's large numbers of students who are Hispanic and English learners. The project will further develop the curriculum, refine the related professional development, scale up the project to 40 additional fourth grade teachers in 10 SAUSD schools, and collect a wide range of qualitative and quantitative data to iteratively improve the project and evaluate its impact on learning processes and outcomes. The project is among the first to examine the linguistic and sociocultural processes that underlie English learners' success in mastering computational thinking, as well as the role of computational thinking in an English language arts curriculum. Materials developed are based on California computer science and English language arts standards and will be actively disseminated to other districts in the state, making them available for use in a state that has the largest amount of Hispanic students (54%) and English learners (20%) in the nation. A team of graduate and undergraduate student researchers in the project, all of whom are Hispanic and/or female, will receive training in diverse research methods for CS education. Information about the project will also be integrated into courses in UC Irvine's Education Sciences Major, Master of Arts in Teaching, CalTeach, and PhD in Education programs, which together serve more than 1000 students per year, the majority of whom are underrepresented minorities and first-generation college students, and the majority of whom continue on to become K-12 or college faculty.

By further developing the curriculum and professional development and implementing it in 40 additional classrooms, the project team will carefully assess the most effective instructional practices in aiding students' computational thinking, developing identity with the field of computer science, and developing academic language proficiency. The curriculum and professional development materials developed and refined through this project will be tailored to the needs of Hispanics and English learners through explicit teaching of CS language functions, inclusion of culturally relevant stories to read and create, and instruction based on collaboration, conversation and inquiry. The RPP team will address research questions focused on teaching such as the challenges and use of the curriculum units and the implications for the professional development; learning including the affects on students' attitudes and knowledge development; and the partnership including describing the ways to enhance the RPP to better address common goals and needs. Using mixed methods, the project will document the scale-up efforts and the development of new tools to support scaling up. Qualitative data will include transcripts from observations and interviews and notes from the design group. The team will analyze these data using grounded theory approaches. The team will collect pre-post quantitative data on students' computational thinking, literacy development, and identification and attitudes toward computer science. Because the data will be both continuous and ordinal, the team will use a range of analytic methods including paired t-tests, Mann-Whitney U tests, analyses of covariance, regressions, and hierarchical linear models to address the research questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Collaborative Network of Grades 3-5 Educators for Computational Thinking for English Learners project has developed, implemented, and evaluated a computational thinking and literacy curriculum tailored to the needs of English learners in grades 3-5. This initiative, conducted in partnership with UC Irvine, Santa Ana Unified School District, Montebello Unified School District, and El Sol Science and Arts Academy, focuses on enhancing computational thinking, literacy skills, and attitudes towards computer science among these students.

Curriculum and Assessment

The project developed and made publicly available the Elementary Computing for All curriculum. This curriculum offers year-long, 45-minute weekly lessons incorporating structured inquiry activities for creative coding, language support for simultaneous development of literacy and computing skills, and exposure to diverse computer scientists to foster STEM identity. We also developed comprehensive teacher resources, including lesson plans, handouts, and professional development programs requiring no prior coding experience, and developed and validated the Assessment of Computing for Elementary Students (ACES), a computational thinking assessment for upper-elementary students.

Implementation

Over 100 teachers participated in ECforALL and received extensive professional development (PD) through summer sessions and monthly meetings. The PD covered the fundamentals of the curriculum, Scratch programming, culturally sustaining pedagogies,and effective teaching methods for English learners in STEM fields. Additionally, we have made a free self-paced Canvas course publicly available to guide teachers to learn and implement the curriculum, featuring modules on pedagogy, curriculum structure, Scratch classroom setup, and detailed instructions on teaching each unit.

Teachers, including those with no prior coding experience, successfully implemented the curriculum in over 100 classrooms across the Santa Ana Unified School District, Montebello Unified School District, and El Sol Science and Arts Academy, reaching over 3,000 students. This success can largely be attributed to the comprehensive professional development and abundant resources provided to the teachers. Despite the occasional breaks for standardized testing and other academic requirements, the teachers maintained consistent delivery of the curriculum.

Findings

Research on the Elementary Computing for All program has shown that incorporating effective strategies for engaging multilingual students in STEM leads to positive social and academic outcomes. Notably, elementary school teachers have been able to successfully teach this curriculum, even without prior experience in coding. The curriculum is particularly beneficial for predominantly low-income Latino students, many of whom are learning English. It helps these students grasp computer science discourse, improve their coding skills, and develop strong computer science identities. 

Computational Thinking Outcomes. A cross-case study revealed that students exposed to structured, inquiry-based learning within this curriculum developed stronger computational thinking skills and computer science identities. The Scratch programming environment provided opportunities for self-expression, where students engaged in key computational thinking practices such as experimenting, iterating, reusing, remixing, testing, debugging, abstracting, and modularizing.

Developing Students' Computer Science Identities. A mixed-methods study showed that students involved in the program experienced an increase in their identification with computer science. This included their experiences with computer science, perceptions about the field, self-perception as computer scientists, and perception of family support for computer science. Further research focused on intersectional factors that shaped young Latinas identity development indicated that parental support, cultural connections, and out-of-school learning were crucial in redefining stereotypes about who participates in computer science, thereby leveraging and valuing the diverse backgrounds and experiences of these students.

Learning Computer Science Disciplinary Language. An analysis of peer-to-peer discussions in students' video reflections on their Scratch projects showed that linguistic scaffolding enhanced their use of computer science vocabulary and understanding of computational thinking practices. Students who more elaborately described their projects and used a wider range of computer science vocabulary achieved higher programming scores. This highlights the importance of peer discussions in strengthening the relationship between the use of computer science language and the development of computing skills.

Dissemination

We have published or presented the findings in more than 65 journals, books, proceedings, and conferences. Our curriculum has been adopted and taught by teachers in Nevada, Indiana, Illinois, Massachusetts, New York, and Brazii, and officially adopted by Boston Public Schools. Our website makes the curriculum in both English and Spanish and other  instructional resources freely available under a Creative Commons license. We also organized and led the first national conference on teaching computer science to multilingual learners in 2021.
